metadata.title: Aqueous tetracycline degradation by coal-based carbon electrocatalytic filtra- tion membrane: effect of nano antimony-doped tin dioxide coating

sections.text:
In this work, a novel electrocatalytic filtration membrane with high degradation
efficiency and low cost was fabricated by coating nano antimony-doped tin dioxide
(Sb-SnO2) on a porous coal-based carbon membrane (CM) through sol-gel method. The nano Sb-SnO2 is homogeneously distributed on the CM surface and is firmly attached to the CM via C-O-Sn chemical bond. Due to the positive effect of nano Sb-SnO2 coating, the Sb-SnO2/CM possesses excellent electrocatalytic activity and shows a much better tetracycline (TC) degradation performance than CM. The TC removal rate of Sb-SnO2/CM could be achieved 96.5% after 6 h operation while that of CM was only 72.8%.
Degradation pathway of TC was also explored using HPLC-MS. Furthermore, the effective
TC degradation is attributed to the synergistic effects of direct and indirect electrochemical oxidation. During the indirect oxidation process, •OH radicals rather than •O2 - play the dominant role.
Key words: Electrocatalytic filtration; Coal-based carbon membrane; Degradation;
Antimony-doped tin dioxide; Tetracycline 1. Introduction
Due to the large application of antibiotics, antibiotics residual has been detected in the
environment and is becoming the emerging contaminants over the past few years [1, 2].
Owing to the seriously adverse effects including ecological risks and human health
damages, the antibiotics residual in aquatic environment has raised considerable concerns
[3]. Tetracycline (TC), as a typical antibiotic, is one of the most used antibiotics to treat and
prevent bacterial infections in human and animal treatment [4, 5]. The concern is that TC
has been detected in different waters such as surface water, groundwater and even drinking
water [6, 7]. At present, the conventional methods such as adsorption, biological methods
and membrane filtration (reverse osmosis and nanofiltration) are not as effective as
anticipated [8, 9]. Therefore, it is a mandatory issue to develop alternative processes to
remove antibiotics from the aquatic environments.
Advanced oxidation processes (AOPs) [10], especially electrochemical oxidation, has
been widely investigated to treat various organic pollutants in recent years and is one of the
most promising technologies to treat antibiotics effectively and environment-friendly [11,
12]. However, the usual electrochemical processes are energy intensive and operated
intermittently, which hinder the extensive application in water treatment. Recently, the
integration of membrane filtration with electrochemical oxidation process creates a hybrid
technology known as electrochemical filtration membrane, which has shown great potential
in treating organic contaminants in water [13]. The electrochemical filtration membrane can
serve as both a separation membrane and an active electrode that can effectively degrade
contaminants by electrochemical reaction. Zaky and Chaplin utilized the porous Ti4O7 as the reactive electrochemical membrane (REM) to remove a series of p-substituted phenolic
compounds [14].Carbon nanotubes (CNTs), with the unique electronic, mechanical and
chemical properties, have received extensive attention in water treatment as an
electrochemical filter [15]. Electrochemical CNT filters have been proven to be a highly
effective technology to remove various contaminants such as dyes, anions, viruses, bacteria,
phenol, and pharmaceutical [16]. Although both of the Ti4O7 and CNT are excellent electrochemical materials, the complexity and high cost in fabricating may limit their
popularization in water treatment field.
The coal-based carbon membrane (CM) is a porous electrode material with high
specific surface area, porosity and conductivity [17]. More importantly, the low cost makes
it an ideal electrochemical filtration membrane [18]. Our previous study also found that CM
could remove TC effectively due to the synergistic effect of electrocatalytic oxidation and
membrane separation [19]. However, the low oxygen evolution potential (OEP) of CM will
reduce the degradation efficiency because of the direct competition between oxygen
evolution and the target organic contaminants oxidation. Moreover, high anode potential
may also accelerate CM corrosion and destruction. Luckily, coal-based CM is an excellent
catalyst substrate with high surface area and surface modification is an effective technique
to improve the anodic OEP. In the field of electrocatalytic research, tin dioxide (SnO2) is an ordinary material coated on anode due to its high OEP (1.7 V vs Ag/AgCl)[20, 21]. SnO2 is
an N-type semiconductor with a large band gap of 3.5 eV and is typically doped with
antinomy (Sb) to heighten the conductivity [22-24]. Therefore, coating a thin layer of
Sb-SnO2 on the coal-based CM may be one strategy to improve the degradation efficiency.
In this work, a CM coated with nano Sb-SnO2 (Sb-SnO2/CM) was fabricated through
sol-gel method and the properties of Sb-SnO2/CM were systematically characterized. TC was selected as the target pollutant for investigating the effect and mechanisms of Sb-SnO2 coating on coal-based CM during electrocatalytic degradation process. Meanwhile, the
intermediates and degradation pathway of TC were evaluated. Furthermore, in order to
deeply understand the electrocatalytic oxidation mechanism of Sb-SnO2, the effect of TC degradation by CM and Sb-SnO2/CM were also investigated by adding appropriate radical scavengers. 2. Materials and methods 2.1. Materials and reagents
In this study, the coal-based CM with mean pore diameter of 0.42 µm and porosity of
44.56% was obtained from Dalian University of Technology [25]. Stannous chloride (SnCl2·2H2O), antimonous chloride (SbCl3), absolute ethyl alcohol (EtOH), tert-butanol (TBA), benzoquinone (BQ) were purchased from Tianjin Feng Chuan Chemical Reagent Technology Co., LTD, China. TC (C22H24N2O8) (98% purity) was purchased from Macklin Biochemical Co., Ltd., Shanghai, China. All of the reagents were used as received without further purification and all aqueous solutions were deionized water (DI water).

sections.heading: 2.2. Preparation of the Sb-SnO2/CM
sections.text:
The flat CM was first pretreated in 65 wt% HNO3 solution for 120 min and washed
with deionized water until the solution pH was neutral, then dried for 100 min at 80 °C [26].
2.25 g SnCl2·2H2O and 0.228 g SbCl3 were added to two flasks containing 100 mL EtOH and 50 mL EtOH, respectively. After violent stirring for 2 h at 80 °C, pouring SbCl3 EtOH solution into SnCl2 EtOH solution, continue to stir for 2 h and aging for 24 h at room temperature, then Sb doped Sn precursor sol was obtained. Next, the treated CM was
dipped into precursor sol for 40 min accompanied by ultrasound, then removed from the sol
and dried at 60 °C for 120 min. Finally, the impregnated CM was put into a muffle furnace
and sintered at 500 °C under nitrogen atmosphere for 120 min, and then the Sb-SnO2/CM was obtained. 2.3. Characterization of the Sb-SnO2/CM
The composition and crystal structure of the as-prepared ceramic membrane were
analyzed by powder X-ray diffraction (XRD; MiniFlex600, Rigaku, Japan) with Cu-Kα radiation (λ = 0.15406 nm) in the scanning angle range of 10-80° at a scanning rate of 2°·min-1. Surface chemical bond was analyzed on X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS; VG ESCALAB MKⅡ, UK) [27, 28]. The morphology and composition of the membrane were characterized by scanning electron microscope (SEM; LEO 1530VP, Germany) attached with an energy dispersive spectroscopy detector (EDS; Trident, USA). The microstructures of the samples were further characterized by high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM; JEM 2010F, Hitachi, Japan).

sections.heading: 2.4. Electrochemical measurements
sections.text:
All the experiments were performed with three electrode cells by electrochemical
workstation (CHI 660E, Chenhua Inc., China). The original and as-prepared CM with an area of 1 cm2 was served as the working electrode and Pt electrode with an area of 1 cm2
was used as counter electrode. An Ag/AgCl electrode was used as reference electrode and
the electrolyte was 0.1 M Na2SO4 at room temperature. OEP was measured by linear scan voltammetry (LSV) at a scan rate of 5 mV·s-1 from 0 to 2.5 V in 0.1 M Na2SO4 electrolyte solution. CV measurements were performed at a scan rate of 5 mV·s-1 and the electrolyte was 5 mM [Fe(CN)6] 3−/[Fe(CN)6] 4− in 0.1 M Na2SO4 solution. Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) experiments were carried out to determine the conductivity of
membrane electrode with the frequency range from 1 MHz to 0.1 Hz at an alternate signal
amplitude of 5 mV in 0.1 M Na2SO4 electrolyte solution. In addition, the accelerated service life tests were performed by the anodic polarization of the CM and Sb-SnO2/CM electrode at current density of 100 mA·cm-2 in 0.1 M Na2SO4 electrolyte solution. The accelerated life of the electrode was defined that when the anode potential increased to 5 V,
the inactivation of working electrode occurred [29]. 2.5. Evaluation of TC removal performance
Fig. 1 Scheme of the electrocatalytic filtration membrane system.
As illustrated in Fig. 1, the experimental device of electrocatalytic membrane filter in a
dead-end manner for TC treatment was designed. A CM or Sb-SnO2/CM with area of 4 cm 2
and thickness of 4 mm was used as anode and a stainless steel mesh with the same area was
used as cathode. They were separated by a silicone rubber ring with 5 mm spacing and
connected to a DC regulated power supply, which constituted the electrocatalytic
membrane filter system. To ensure the membrane surface is clean, both the CM and
Sb-SnO2/CM were rinsed with 100 mL EtOH and 200 mL DI water prior to use.
The TC concentration was detected by using high-performance liquid chromatography
(HPLC; Waters 2695) [19, 30]. The total organic carbon (TOC) was measured using a
Shimadzu TOC-VCPH total organic carbon analyzer. To clarify the possible degradation intermediates of TC, HPLC coupling with quadrupole time of flight mass spectrometry
detector (MS; micrOTOF-Q II) was employed. The column used was Agilent Extend-C18
and the mobile phase was a mixture of methanol and water (1:1, V/V) in an isocratic system at a flow rate of 1 mL·min-1. The mass spectrometer was operated in positive ion
mode with a capillary voltage of 4.5 kV. The gas pressure of nebulizer nitrogen was set at
0.8 bar and the dry heater temperature was set at 180 °C. 3. Results and discussion 3.1. Composition and structural characterization
Fig. 2 XRD patterns of CM and Sb-SnO2/CM.
The X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis was performed to reveal the composition and
crystal phases of the original CM and Sb-SnO2/CM. As shown in Fig. 2, the XRD pattern of CM exhibits two broad diffraction peaks at 2θ = 20-30 and 40-50°, which can be indexed to
(002) and (100) diffraction peaks of amorphous carbon [31]. The diffraction peaks of
Sb-SnO2/CM located at 20-30 and 40-50° were consistent with that of the original CM. The other peaks located at 26.6, 33.9, 37.9 and 52.0° were assigned to (110), (101), (200) and
(211) respectively, which could be well indexed to tetragonal rutile structure of SnO2 (JCPDS No. 41-1445). Since the amount of doping Sb element is very little, no obvious
diffraction peaks attributed to Sb compounds are detected for Sb-SnO2/CM. Moreover, the average grain size of Sb-SnO2 can be estimated about 7 nm by using the Scherrer equation associated with (110) crystalline faces.
D = .
(1)
In Eq. (1), D is the particle size, λ is the wavelength of the X-ray analysis (λ = 0.154
nm), β is the full width at half maximum of the diffraction peak and θ is the Bragg angle.
The microstructures of the CM and Sb-SnO2/CM were observed by SEM and TEM.
As shown in Fig. 3a, 3b and Fig. S1a, S1b in Supporting Information, both the original CM
and Sb-SnO2/CM are constituted by a large number of carbon particles with a very rough, which results in a large specific surface area, favorable for loading Sb-SnO2 and adsorption of organic pollutants. However, compared with the CM, no apparent Sb-SnO2 particles are observed on the Sb-SnO2/CM surface by SEM analysis which may be due to the small size of Sb-SnO2.
The morphologies were further studied by TEM observation (Fig. 3c and 3d). The CM
is composed completely by amorphous carbon and no other nanoparticles are observed (Fig.
3c). However, as evidenced from Fig. 3d, there are distinct nanoparticles with cubic
structure and with average size of about 6.89 nm on the surface of Sb-SnO2/CM (Fig. 3e). Moreover, the high resolution image confirms the nanostructured particles are crystalline
with clear lattice fringes. The interlayer distance of lattice fringes is 0.326 nm, which
corresponds to the (101) lattice plane of tetragonal SnO2 [32]. The results indicate that the nano Sb-SnO2 are well deposited on the surface of Sb-SnO2/CM, which could enhance the electrocatalytic activity of the electrode membrane and improve the electrocatalytic
performance.
Further evidence of the chemical composition of CM and Sb-SnO2/CM could be
obtained from EDS and XPS analysis (Fig. S2 and Table S1, S2 in Supporting
Information). The main elements of the CM are C (86.73 wt%) and O (9.59 wt%), and
other trace elements like Si and S are also detected. However, Sn (8.56 wt%) and Sb (1.72
wt%) are obviously contained on the Sb-SnO2/CM surface, and the C content decreases to 74.89 wt% while the O content increases to 11.84 wt% correspondingly. The increase of Sn
and O content and decrease of C content in the Sb-SnO2/CM surface may be interpreted that the precursor sol is transformed into SnO2. In addition, as shown in Fig. 3f, elemental mapping further verifies that Sn, Sb and O elements are homogeneously distributed on the
In order to gain further insights into the chemical bonding situation of Sb-SnO2/CM,
XPS was carried out. The survey spectrum of Sb-SnO2/CM (Fig. 4a) reveals the presence of C, O and Sn element, which is in good agreement with the EDS result. Fig. 4b shows the
high-resolution spectrum of the Sn 3d region of Sb-SnO2/CM. The peaks of Sn are symmetric and appear at 487.3 eV (Sn 3d5/2) and 495.7 eV (Sn 3d3/2), which are assigned to the lattice Sn in SnO2 [33]. The distance between Sn 3d3/2 and Sn 3d5/2 is equal to 8.4 eV, which definitely confirms the formation of SnO2. Observing the Fig. 4f, the binding energy peak located at 540.9 eV is assigned to Sb 3d3/2, and the Sb 3d5/2 spectrum is overlapped with the O 1s at around 531.4 eV [34]. This result proves the formation of Sb2O5 in antimony-doped tin dioxide compound.
O1s peak has an obvious shift due to the SnO2 coating (Fig. 4 e, 4f). It suggests that
there was a new chemical bond generated between SnO2 and carbon membrane [26, 35]. Fig. 4c and 4d show the high resolution spectra of the C 1s region of CM and Sb-SnO2/CM. For CM, the main peak positioned at about 284.9 eV is attributed to non-oxygenated ring carbon atoms like C-C bond (sp2 C), while the other two peaks at 286.5 and 289.1 eV are
assigned to C-O and O-C=O bonds, respectively. In Fig. 4d, the peak intensity of the C-O
bond noticeably increases, and the C-C decrease correspondingly. This is because the
partial carbon atoms of CM form C-O bond with oxygen atoms derived from SnO2, generating new C-O-Sn chemical bond between the CM and coated SnO2, therefore the peak intensity of the C-O bond of Sb-SnO2/CM increases. Due to the formation of C-O-Sn chemical bond between CM and Sb-SnO2 nanoparticles, the nano Sb-SnO2 coating is firmly
fixed on CM surface via C-O-Sn bond, which greatly enhances the adhesion and stability of
the nano coating. 3.2. Electrochemical characterization
Fig. 5 LSV (a), CV (b), EIS (c), and accelerated lifetime test (d) curves of CM and Sb-SnO2/CM (Electrode area: 1 cm 2, Temperature: 25 °C, CV test in 0.1 M Na2SO4 and 5 mM [Fe(CN)6] 3−/[Fe(CN)6] 4− solution and the other test in 0.1 M Na2SO4 solution).
The electrochemical performance of the Sb-SnO2/CM was studied to examine the impact of nano Sb-SnO2 on the electrochemical oxidation capability of the membrane electrode. The OEP is usually used as the indicator of electrochemical oxidation ability, and
a higher OEP means a lower side reaction of oxygen evolution and a higher current
efficiency, which will be beneficial to promote the electrochemical oxidation efficiency of
organic pollutants. As shown in Fig. 5a, LSV curves were measured to characterize the
OEP of the membrane electrodes, and the extrapolation (dashed lines) of the current curves
to 0 mA was used to obtain the OEP value [36]. The OEPs were 1.58 V and 1.31 V (vs
Ag/AgCl)) for the Sb-SnO2/CM and CM electrode, respectively. Obviously, the OEP of Sb-SnO2/CM electrode was remarkably enhanced. Moreover, the anodic current of Sb-SnO2/CM could reach 42 mA at 2.5 V (vs Ag/AgCl), maintaining a higher current response. Therefore, owing to the surface modification of nano Sb-SnO2, the Sb-SnO2/CM has better electrochemical performance.
CV measurements were performed to explore the electrocatalytic activity of CM and
Sb-SnO2/CM electrodes. As can be seen from Fig. 5b, the anodic peak current (Ipa) of Sb-SnO2/CM (2.85 mA·cm -2) is much higher than that of CM (2 mA·cm-2). In the meantime, the CV curve of Sb-SnO2/CM shows a shift in both anodic and cathodic peaks. Compared with CM, the anodic peak of Sb-SnO2/CM exhibited a negative shift while the cathodic peak exhibited a positive shift. Thus the potential difference between anodic and
cathodic peak potentials was reduced from 0.139 V to 0.111 V vs Ag/AgCl, which
indicates Sb-SnO2/CM electrode has better reversibility and electrocatalytic activity for the [Fe(CN)6] 3−/[Fe(CN)6] 4− redox pair. Therefore, it can be concluded that Sb-SnO2 coating is of benefit to the electrochemical performance.
EIS is an effective method for exploring the changes of electron transfer resistance of
surface modified electrode. Fig. 5c is the EIS curves of CM and Sb-SnO2/CM electrodes.
The electrochemical impedances (the diameter of the semicircle) of CM and Sb-SnO2/CM are 4.03 Ω and 5.62 Ω, respectively, which reveals the electron transfer on the interface of
Sb-SnO2/CM electrode and solution is not seriously impeded by the loaded Sb-SnO2. The reason is that the Sb-SnO2/CM surface is not completely covered by Sb-SnO2 nanoparticles and the Sb-SnO2 nanoparticles are uniformly distributed on membrane surface, which is proved by the SEM and EDS results. Thus, the transfer of electron between Sb-SnO2/CM electrode and solution still maintains a high rate, and the whole Sb-SnO2/CM electrode still shows good conductivity.
The stability of membrane electrode is the main restraining factor for their applications.
However stability test of membrane electrode under normal conditions is time consuming.
To shorten the test time, the accelerated lifetime test was performed to evaluate the service
lifetime of the membrane electrode [37]. As can be seen from Fig. 5d, the accelerated
lifetime of Sb-SnO2/CM electrode reaches up to 9.25 h, which is much longer than that of the original CM electrode (~2.2 h). Compared with Sb-SnO2/CM, the original CM produces more oxygen under the same current density due to the lower OEP. So the CM surface is
covered by a large amount of gas bubbles, which hinders the electronic transmission
between the CM surface and solution and results in a higher anode potential of CM. High
anode potential causes the carbon materials corrode more easily [36]. In the meantime, the
gas bubbles with high energy may strike the CM surface continuously and then accelerate
the corrosion of CM. Consequently, the nano Sb-SnO2 coating on CM surface improves the electrode stability for the higher OEP.
In summary, owing to the effect of nano Sb-SnO2 coating, the Sb-SnO2/CM has the higher OEP, excellent electrocatalytic activity, superior stability, and maintains a good
electrical conductivity, which is expected to have good electrocatalytic performance. 3.3. TC removal performance of electrocatalytic filtration membrane
To evaluate the performance of electrocatalytic filtration membrane for the removal of
TC and the contribution of Sb-SnO2 coating, TC solution was treated by using CM and Sb-SnO2/CM. As shown in Fig. 6, the removal rate of TC by Sb-SnO2/CM could maintain a high removal rate as the operating time increases. The TC removal rate could be achieved
99.3% during the first hour and the TC removal rate of 98.2% and 96.5% could be achieved
after 3 h and 6 h operation, respectively. In contrast, the removal rate of TC by CM could
obtain a high removal rate at the beginning, while the removal rate decreased sharply along
with the operation time, and only 72.8% could be achieved after 6 h operation. Both the
Sb-SnO2/CM and CM could obtain a high removal rate of TC at the early stage of operation, which is attributed to the adsorption effect of porous carbon materials. The SEM images
(Fig. 3a and 3b) show the surfaces of CM and Sb-SnO2/CM are very rough, resulting in a large specific surface area. Therefore the CM has certain adsorption ability for TC and the
adsorption breakthrough curve of TC by CM in the absence of electrochemical assistance is
shown in Fig. S3 in Supporting Information. As shown in Fig. S3, the removal rate of TC is
not ideal only by self-adsorption owing to the limited adsorption capacity of CM.
To further clarify the TC removal mechanism of electrocatalytic membrane, TOC
analyses were carried out. The TOC removal rate of Sb-SnO2/CM is far higher than that of CM, and the TOC removal rate of both Sb-SnO2/CM and CM is not as good as TC removal rate. This is mainly due to the accumulation effect of TC molecules on the membrane,
resulting in the TC molecules could not be degraded completely. Nevertheless, the TOC
removal rate also illustrates that Sb-SnO2/CM has better degradation performance for TC than CM.
In the literature, Liu et al reported a CNT electrochemical filter was fabricated to
degrade aqueous TC [38]. The TC removal rate by CNT electrochemical filter was about 94%
after 3 h, while the TC removal rate by Sb-SnO2/CM was 98% and 96% after 3 h and 6 h in our experiments. Though the removal performance of CM for TC is less than that of CNT,
the removal performance of Sb-SnO2/CM is much better than that of CNT. In conclusion, Sb-SnO2/CM has superior electrocatalytic performance and stability, which demonstrates
that the Sb-SnO2/CM is suitable for efficient and continuous degradation of organic pollutants. Moreover, taking into account the cost, the Sb-SnO2/CM will have a better prospect of application in the field of water treatment than CNTs.
Fig. 7 Effect of cell voltage on TC removal rate of Sb-SnO2/CM (a) and CM (b); TOC removal rate of Sb-SnO2/CM (c) and CM (d) (TC concentration: 50 mg·L -1, Flow rate: 1 mL·min-1, Temperature: 25 °C).
The electrocatalytic oxidation efficiency could be influenced greatly by cell voltage.
Therefore, the effect of cell voltage on TC and TOC removal rate was studied from 0 to 4 V
with 2 h operation. As displayed in Fig. 7a and 7b, in the absence of electrochemical
assistance, the TC removal rates of CM and Sb-SnO2/CM are 22.1% and 23.4%, respectively. Since the size of the TC molecule is much smaller than the membrane pore,
the TC molecule could not be removed by the sieving effect of CM or Sb-SnO2/CM and only could be partially adsorbed on the membrane. At cell voltage of 0.5 V, the TC removal
rate of CM and Sb-SnO2/CM slightly increased, and it further increased with increasing
voltage. Moreover, the TC removal rate of Sb-SnO2/CM was obviously much higher than that of CM. As shown in Fig. 7a, the TC removal rate could achieve nearly 100% at 3.5 V.
However, the TC removal rate of CM rose to 84% at 3 V then decreased to 80% as the
voltage increased to 4 V (Fig. 7b). The results show that the Sb-SnO2/CM has the better TC treatment efficiency than CM and the TC molecular structure could be destroyed by
electrocatalytic oxidation. This is ascribed to the fact that the amount of reactive oxidizing
groups such as •OH increase at high cell voltage. As for the decline of TC removal rate for
CM at high cell voltage, this is ascribed to the low OEP of CM. The low OEP promotes
oxygen evolution reaction and results in a large number of bubbles which clog the TC
molecule in contact with the CM surface [26]. Besides, the CM has poor stability at higher
potential and the inner structure may be damaged. The two factors together contributed to
the decrease of TC removal rate at high cell voltage.
From Fig. 7c and 7d, the TOC removal rate represents a similar variation tendency like
that of TC removal rate. The main reason is that TC molecules are not completely
decomposed and form intermediate products which are not easy to mineralize. Despite the
incomplete mineralization of TC, the Sb-SnO2/CM behaves high TOC removal rate owing to the effect of nano Sb-SnO2 coating.
As shown in Fig. 6 and Fig. 7, the TOC removal rate could not achieve 100%, and this
may be attributed to the formation of some intermediates in the degradation process. In
order to further clarify the degradation process of TC, HPLC-MS analysis was employed.
The HPLC-MS chromatograms of TC solution after degradation are shown in Fig. S4 in
Supporting Information and some main intermediate products with m/z value like 418, 362,
306, 262, 246, 226, 218 and 164 are found. Generally, the intermediates were mainly
decomposed by the loss of functional groups and ring-opening reaction during the
electricalcatalytic oxidation process. Based on the HPLC-MS results and previous studies, a
feasible pathway of TC degradation is proposed in Fig. 8. The intermediate B with m/z =
401 might be attributed to the deamidation process of TC (A, m/z = 445), then the
hydroxylation of B by the electrophilic addition of •OH forms product C with m/z = 418.
With the reaction of dehydroxylation, demethylation and deamination and further breakage
of C2-C3 bond is attacked by •OH, product C is transformed into product D with m/z = 362.
As the electrocatalytic reactions proceed, the ring-opening reactions occur to generate
product E (m/z = 306), F (m/z = 262), G (m/z = 246), H (m/z = 226), I (m/z = 164) and J
(m/z = 218). Finally, even further being oxidized, these intermediates are transferred into
CO2 and H2O. 3.4 Electrocatalytic oxidation mechanism of Sb-SnO2/CM
developed to prepare Sb-SnO2/CM with high degradation efficiency. The nano Sb-SnO2 is
homogeneously distributed on the CM surface and is firmly attached to the CM via C-O-Sn
chemical bond, which enhances the stability of the nano Sb-SnO2 coating. The Sb-SnO2/CM possesses the higher OEP, electrocatalytic activity and stability, and maintains a good
electrical conductivity. Thus the Sb-SnO2/CM shows a much better degradation performance of TC than CM due to the excellent electrochemical properties. As a result, the
TC removal rate of 96.5% could be achieved after 6 h operation. Furthermore, the
electrocatalytic oxidation mechanism of Sb-SnO2/CM is the synergistic effects of direct and indirect electrochemical oxidation and •OH radicals play the dominant role in the indirect
oxidation process. It is convinced that the Sb-SnO2/CM will have wide application potentials for antibiotics pollutants removal in water treatment field.
Acknowledgements: This work was supported by the National Natural Science Foundation
of China (No.51478461 and No. 51202292).

referenceMentions.context: Introduction Due to the large application of antibiotics, antibiotics residual has been detected in the environment and is becoming the emerging contaminants over the past few years [1, 2].
Introduction Due to the large application of antibiotics, antibiotics residual has been detected in the environment and is becoming the emerging contaminants over the past few years [1, 2].
Tetracycline (TC), as a typical antibiotic, is one of the most used antibiotics to treat and prevent bacterial infections in human and animal treatment [4, 5].

metadata.abstractText: In this work, a novel electrocatalytic filtration membrane with high degradation efficiency and low cost was fabricated by coating nano antimony-doped tin dioxide (Sb-SnO2) on a porous coal-based carbon membrane (CM) through sol-gel method. The nano Sb-SnO2 is homogeneously distributed on the CM surface and is firmly attached to the CM via C-O-Sn chemical bond. Due to the positive effect of nano Sb-SnO2 coating, the Sb-SnO2/CM possesses excellent electrocatalytic activity and shows a much better tetracycline (TC) degradation performance than CM. The TC removal rate of Sb-SnO2/CM could be achieved 96.5% after 6 h operation while that of CM was only 72.8%. Degradation pathway of TC was also explored using HPLC-MS. Furthermore, the effective TC degradation is attributed to the synergistic effects of direct and indirect electrochemical oxidation. During the indirect oxidation process, •OH radicals rather than •O2 play the dominant role. 2
